about.paragraph1: This is a collaborative page that was created as a digital space for society, researchers and the government to interact and share information, projects and research about the Bath of Saint John of Corumbá – Mato Grosso do Sul, especially to support the safeguarding of tradition, promote the reproduction and sustainability of the festivity.
about.paragraph2: Recognized by the Government of the State of Mato Grosso do Sul in 2010 as intangible historical and cultural heritage, the Bath of Saint John of Corumbá and Ladário (MS), a common asset registered as national intangible heritage by the National Institute of Historical and Artistic Heritage (IPHAN) in the Book of Celebrations Registration in 2021.
about.paragraph3: This space, now managed by the municipality of Corumbá, aims to maintain collaborative governance, and in this way, we invite you to participate in the Map of the Culture of the Bath of Saint John of Corumbá.
about.paragraph4: Here you can research cultural heritage, submit your research on the topic, access and register your party community and share it for free, recover stories and contribute to the preservation of this intangible heritage.
about.paragraph5: The page was initially structured collaboratively based on the multimedia framework provided - Deus te Salve João Batista! A contribution on the bath of São João de Corumbá, awarded in 2012 at the 25th Edition of the Rodrigo Melo Franco de Andrade Prize, from the National Institute of Historical and Artistic Heritage (Iphan), proposed by researcher Ma. Hélènemarie Dias Fernandes.

testimonials_page.description: Watch and share testimonials from people who keep alive the tradition of the Bath of Saint John in the Pantanal region. Each story reveals a different aspect of this rich cultural manifestation.

quotes.1: My family has been celebrating the Bath of Saint John for five generations. It is a tradition that connects us with our ancestors and keeps our Pantaneiro culture alive.
quotes.2: As a riverside resident, I've always had a special relationship with the river. The Bath of Saint John is a moment to be grateful for the abundance that the waters provide us.
quotes.3: Preserving the traditions of the Bath of Saint John means preserving our cultural identity. During the celebrations, our music accompanies the procession and traditional dances.
quotes.4: As a long-time resident, I find in the Bath of Saint John a perfect example of the religious and cultural syncretism that forms the Brazilian Pantaneiro identity.
quotes.5: I made a promise to Saint John when my son was ill. After his recovery, we participate every year in the bathing ritual, keeping our commitment to the saint.
quotes.6: Our family preserves the songs and dances that celebrate Saint John for generations. Music is fundamental to transmit this cultural heritage.
quotes.7: My grandmother was a healer and used herbs and Saint John's holy water in her treatments. I learned from her the medicinal and spiritual value of this tradition.
quotes.8: As a faith healer, I use the blessed herbs during the Saint John's festival. The water collected on this night is considered mythical and healing.
quotes.9: I've been organizing the festival for over 20 years and have seen how it has transformed while maintaining its essence. It's gratifying to see young people taking interest in our traditions.
quotes.10: In my community, the celebrations of the Bath of Saint John connect people and strengthen our bonds. It is a cultural manifestation that unites us as a people.
quotes.11: As a fisherman, I have a special relationship with Saint John and the waters of the Pantanal. The bath is a moment of renewal and gratitude for the abundance.
quotes.12: In my family, the festival is a moment of gathering and thanksgiving. We prepare typical foods and receive neighbors to celebrate this tradition together.
quotes.13: As a musician, I see in the celebration of the Bath of Saint John a unique cultural richness, where traditional rhythms preserve our collective memory.
quotes.14: I study the traditions of the Bath of Saint John as part of my research. It's impressive how this practice connects indigenous, European, and African elements.
quotes.15: I learned to prepare the herbs and elements of the altar from my grandmother. Each plant has a meaning and purpose in the celebration.
quotes.16: I prepare Saint John's altar every year following exactly the teachings I received from my mother. Each element has a special meaning in the tradition.
quotes.17: My experience with the Bath of Saint John began when I made a promise for my father's health. Since then, it has been an annual practice of gratitude.
quotes.18: I actively participate in the Saint John's festivities since I was a child. The traditions of Arraiá Nhá Concha are a fundamental part of our cultural identity.
quotes.19: As an artisan, I create pieces inspired by the symbolism of the Bath of Saint John. It's a way to keep this rich and diverse cultural expression alive.
